title: Big infra funds set sights on Queensland gas assets
text:
Infrastructure funds are brushing up on LNG plants, pipes and jetties, in expectation of a potential asset selldown in Queensland by global major Royal Dutch Shell.

As the big domestic infrastructure teams start thinking about assets up for grabs in the new year, it is understood their focus has turned to so-called "common facilities" at Shell's QCLNG venture, which is one of the big LNG exporters in Queensland.

Investment bank Rothschild is understood to be working with Shell to help consider its options at the project, including thinking about ways to release capital via the sale and leaseback of its infrastructure assets.

Shell took control of the Queensland Curtis LNG project as part of its $70 billion takeover of BG Group.

Should the deliberations progress beyond the scoping phase - and there is indications that they will - it would be a big move for Shell and something that would be closely watched by rival gas project owners and infrastructure investors.

Shell owns QGC, which has a majority stake in the QCLNG project.
description: Infrastructure funds are brushing up on LNG plants in expectation of a local asset selldown by Royal Dutch Shell.
